definitions.definition: a written text that can be published in printed or electronic form:

examples.original: Have you read any good books recently?
He has a new book out (= published).
She wrote a book on car maintenance.

definitions.definition: a set of pages that have been fastened together inside a cover to be read or written in:

examples.original: a hardback/paperback book
I took a book with me to read on the plane.
He writes all his expenses in a little book he carries with him.

definitions.definition: a number of one type of thing fastened together flat inside a cover:

examples.original: a book of stamps/tickets/matches

definitions.definition: one of the parts that a very long book, such as the Bible, is divided into:

examples.original: the book of Job

definitions.definition: the written records of money that a business has spent or received:

examples.original: Running a school is much more of a business than it used to be, - by law we have to balance our books.

definitions.definition: the situation in which a bookmaker accepts and pays out amounts of money that are risked on a particular result:

examples.original: They've already opened/started a book on the result of the next World Cup.

definitions.definition: to arrange to have a seat, room, performer, etc. at a particular time in the future:

examples.original: I'd like to go but I'm booked up (= I have arranged to do other things) until the weekend.
The hotel/restaurant/theatre is fully booked (= all the rooms/tables/tickets have been taken).
I've booked us two tickets to see 'Carmen'/I've booked two tickets for us to see 'Carmen'.
She'd booked a table for four at their favourite restaurant.
Will booked a seat on the evening flight to Los Angeles.
We were advised to book early if we wanted to get a room.
They booked a jazz band for their wedding.

definitions.definition: If a police officer, referee, etc. books someone, they write down the person's name in an official record because they have done something wrong:

examples.original: A football player who is booked twice in a game is sent off the field.
My grandmother was booked for speeding last week.

definitions.definition: If you give up a habit, such as smoking, or something such as alcohol, you stop doing it or using it:

examples.original: I gave up smoking two years ago.
Don't offer him a cigarette, he's trying to give it up.

definitions.definition: to stop doing a regular activity or job:

examples.original: He's given up driving since his illness.
We're going to give up our sports club membership after this year.

definitions.definition: to stop doing something before you have finished it, usually because it is too difficult:

examples.original: I've given up trying to help her.

definitions.definition: to stop trying to guess:

examples.original: You'll never guess the answer - do you give up?
I give up - how many were there?

definitions.definition: to stop owning, using, or claiming something:

examples.original: They were forced to give up their home because they couldn't pay the mortgage.

definitions.definition: to stop hoping that a particular thing will happen:

examples.original: We still haven't given up hope of finding her alive.

definitions.definition: used to ask people to clap their hands to show their enjoyment or approval of a performance:

examples.original: Ladies and gentlemen, will you give it up for Danny Jones.

definitions.definition: to stop having a friendship with someone:

examples.original: She seems to have given up all her old friends.

definitions.definition: to stop expecting that someone will arrive:

examples.original: I've been waiting half an hour - I'd almost given up on you.

definitions.definition: to think that someone is certain to die or to be dead:

examples.original: The doctors had virtually given her up for dead, but she eventually recovered.

definitions.definition: to allow the police or an enemy to take you as a prisoner:

examples.original: The gunman gave himself up to the police.

definitions.definition: to offer something to someone, or to provide someone with something:

examples.original: She gave us a set of saucepans as a wedding present.
Can you give me a date for another appointment?
They never gave me a chance/choice.
Has the director given you permission to do that?
We always try to give to charity.
We're collecting for the children's home - please give generously.
The police gave (out) road-safety booklets to the children (= gave them to all the children).
Please give (up) your seat to an elderly or disabled person if they need it.

definitions.definition: to tell someone something:

examples.original: The winner's name was given (out)/They gave the winner's name (out) on the news.
Can you give Jo a message for me?

definitions.definition: to perform an action:

examples.original: She gave me a smile/strange look.
They had to give the car a push to start it.
Give me a call/ring (= phone me) when you get back from holiday.
Who is giving the speech/lecture/concert?

definitions.definition: to organize a party, meal, etc.:

examples.original: They're always giving parties.
The ambassador is giving a banquet for the visiting president.

definitions.definition: to pay someone a particular amount:

examples.original: I gave the taxi driver £20 and told him to keep the change.

definitions.definition: to allow a person or activity a particular amount of time:

examples.original: I'm nearly ready - just give me a couple of minutes.

definitions.definition: to produce or cause something:

examples.original: The fresh air gave us an appetite (= made us hungry).
What you said has given me an idea.
The alarm gave (out) a high-pitched sound.

definitions.definition: to give your money, time, or best efforts, especially in a way that seems generous:

examples.original: We're very grateful to all the people who have given of their time.

definitions.definition: to put a lot of effort into doing something:

examples.original: We must be finished by tonight, so I want you to give it your all.

definitions.definition: to punish someone by sending them to prison for a particular period:

examples.original: If you're found guilty, they'll give you three years.

definitions.definition: to calculate that something will last a particular amount of time:

examples.original: Look at that old car she bought - I give it two weeks before it breaks down.

definitions.definition: to tell someone something or cause someone to think that something is true:

examples.original: I was given to understand she was staying at this hotel.

definitions.definition: to tell someone something or cause someone to think that something is true:

examples.original: Upon quitting home, she gave it to be understood that she was about to visit her aunt in the Rue des Drômes.
He even gave it to be understood that there has been some kind of massacre.
I did not say, as you gave it to be believed, that the gentleman was to blame.

definitions.definition: to attempt something:

examples.original: Only a few people are successful as professional athletes, but it's worth giving it a go.

definitions.definition: to say publicly that everyone present at a formal occasion, especially a meal, should drink a toast to someone (= have a drink in honour of someone):

examples.original: Ladies and Gentlemen, I give you the president!

definitions.definition: If something gives, it stretches, bends, or breaks, or becomes less firm or tight, under pressure:

examples.original: The rope gave under/with the weight of the load.
The shoes will give a little after you've worn them once or twice.
You can't work so hard all the time - something will have to give (= change).
Suddenly her patience gave (out) and she shouted angrily at the children.

definitions.definition: in some sports, to decide and state officially that a player or the ball is in a particular condition or place:

examples.original: The umpire gave the batsman out.
The ball was clearly out, but the line judge gave it in.

definitions.definition: the quality of stretching, bending, or breaking, or becoming less firm or tight, under pressure:

examples.original: A sweater knitted in pure cotton doesn't have much give (= will not stretch much).

definitions.definition: something you say to greet someone politely when you meet them in the afternoon
